Legal_Issue: Whether the Prothonotary erred in dismissing Bayer's prohibition application as clearly futile
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence did not establish that PPC's Product Monograph sufficiently influenced healthcare practitioners
Burden_of_Proof: PPC met its burden to show Bayer's application had no reasonable chance of success
Legal_Rule: A motion to strike may be granted if the application is scandalous, frivolous, or an abuse of process, and it is plain and obvious that it has no chance of success
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged inducement of patent infringement via Product Monograph
Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed as having no reasonable chance of success
Decision_Maker: Prothonotary Lafrenière, followed by appellate review
Review_Standard: Plain and obvious test for futility
Key_Evidence_Considered: PPC Product Monograph, expert testimony on influence over prescribing practices
Standard_of_Proof: No reasonable chance of success (plain and obvious standard)
Defendant_Response: PPC filed a motion to strike, arguing the claim was futile
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition order against approval of generic drug
Outcome: Bayer's application dismissed; PPC awarded costs
Remedy_Sought: Injunction to prevent regulatory approval based on patent infringement
Claimant_Status: Bayer as innovator company holding the 424 Patent
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Claim was frivolous, scandalous, or an abuse of process
Applicable_Process: Regulatory approval process under NOC Regulations
